sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.title: Understanding security tactics in microservice APIs using annotated software architecture decomposition models–a controlled experiment
sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.abstract:
While microservice architectures have become a widespread option for designing distributed applications, designing secure microservice systems remains challenging. Although various security-related guidelines and practices exist, these systems' sheer size, complex communication structures, and polyglot tech stacks make it difficult to manually validate whether adequate security tactics are applied throughout their architecture. To address these challenges, we have devised a novel solution that involves the automatic generation of security-annotated software decomposition models and the utilization of security-based metrics to guide software architectures through the assessment of security tactics employed within microservice systems. To evaluate the effectiveness of our artifacts, we conducted a controlled experiment where we asked 60 students from two universities and ten experts from the industry to identify and assess the security features of two microservice reference systems. During the experiment, we tracked the correctness of their answers and the time they needed to solve the given tasks to measure how well they could understand the security tactics applied in the reference systems. Our results indicate that the supplemental material significantly improved the correctness of the participants' answers without requiring them to consult the documentation more. Most participants also stated in a self-assessment that their understanding of the security tactics used in the systems improved significantly because of the provided material, with the additional diagrams considered very helpful. In contrast, the perception of architectural metrics varied widely. We could also show that novice developers benefited most from the supplementary diagrams. In contrast, senior developers could rely on their experience to compensate for the lack of additional help. Contrary to our expectations, we found no significant correlation between the time spent solving the tasks and the overall correctness score achieved, meaning that participants who took more time to read the documentation did not automatically achieve better results. As far as we know, this empirical study is the first analysis that explores the influence of security annotations in component diagrams to guide software developers when assessing microservice system security.

Communicated by: Barbora Buhnova

sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemScope: The scope includes the application of security tactics in microservice architectures, particularly in the context of their APIs and the difficulties in manually validating security due to system complexity.

sciknow-25x1-research-questions.questionText: How do security-annotated component diagrams aid engineers in understanding microservice security architectures?
How do security-annotated component diagrams affect the time required to understand security aspects of a microservice system?
Do participants achieve better results when spending more time reading the documentation and answering the questions?
How well did the participants perceive the component diagrams and metrics and is there a noticeable difference in the use of the materials?

sciknow-25x1-research-questions.questionText: Do our diagrams and metrics benefit users differently based on their industry experience and compensate for limited expertise?

sciknow-25x1-scientific-challenges.challengeDescription: Designing secure microservice systems is challenging due to the sheer size, complex communication structures, and polyglot tech stacks, making it difficult to manually validate whether adequate security tactics are applied throughout their architecture.

Documenting microservices is challenging due to the rapid evolution of these systems and their polyglot nature, often resulting in manual documentation efforts that are difficult to keep in sync with the actual state of development.

The discrepancy between manual documentation and the actual state of development can lead to incomplete or ambiguous documentation, which is a fundamental difficulty in maintaining accurate and up-to-date system documentation.
The lack of widespread acceptance of the AsyncAPI specification, compared to the OpenAPI specification for REST APIs, presents a challenge in documenting asynchronous communication in microservices.

The intrinsic complexity of microservice systems, with their autonomous service units and independent actions, presents a challenge in understanding and managing the communication and security tactics within the system.

sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.name: Understanding security tactics in microservice APIs using annotated software architecture decomposition models
sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.description: The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of automatically generated security-annotated software decomposition models and the utilization of security-based metrics to guide software architectures in assessing security tactics employed within microservice systems. A controlled experiment was conducted with participants from academia and industry to measure their understanding of security tactics applied in reference microservice systems.

studyDesign.designDetails: A within-subject experimental design was used, where each participant served as a member of the Experiment Group for one task while at the same time being part of the Control Group for the other task. The order of the example architectures was varied to avoid bias through learning effects.

populationAndSampling.targetPopulation: Participants included 60 students from two universities with backgrounds in computer science studies and 10 industry experts with verified experience.
populationAndSampling.inclusionCriteria: Participants were either enrolled in or graduated from computer science studies or were industry experts with experience in software development.

variables.conceptualDefinition: The correctness of participants' answers when identifying and assessing security features of microservice reference systems.
variables.operationalization: Measured by tracking the correctness of answers to multiple-choice, cloze, and free-text questions.

variables.conceptualDefinition: The time taken by participants to complete the questionnaire, including reading the documentation and answering the questions.
variables.operationalization: Participants recorded the time they spent on each question and the time spent reading the documentation.

steps.description: Participants were provided with background information on microservice systems and security tactics two weeks before the experiment.
steps.outputs: Participants' understanding of microservice systems and security tactics

steps.description: Participants were given a survey containing several questions focusing on certain security aspects of the system's architecture.
steps.inputs: Printed documentation, component diagrams, metrics tables (for Experiment Group)

steps.description: Participants self-assessed their performance and the support provided by the materials through a Likert-Scale questionnaire.

procedures.procedureDescription: Participants were asked to evaluate two open-source reference microservice architectures by answering a set of questions designed to assess their understanding of the security tactics implemented in the systems. The Experiment Group received additional material in the form of annotated component diagrams and metrics tables, while the Control Group only had access to the regular documentation.

dataCollection.instrumentDescription: A structured survey questionnaire was used to collect data on participants' correctness and response time. A self-assessment questionnaire was also used to gather feedback on their performance and the support provided by the materials.
dataCollection.collectionSetting: University settings for students and online for industry experts.
dataCollection.collectionTimeframe: Data collection occurred during the controlled experiment sessions.

dataAnalysis.statisticalTests: Cliff's δ, Spearman's rank correlation coefficient, Kruskal-Wallis test, Wilcoxon Rank Sum test
dataAnalysis.summary: Data analysis involved calculating the Correctness and Response Time for each participant and comparing these metrics between the Control and Experiment Groups. Non-parametric statistical tests such as Cliff's δ and Spearman's rank correlation coefficient were used to test for significance and correlation. The analysis also included a descriptive statistics analysis of self-assessment scores and the effect of industry experience on the Correctness.

resultsRepresentation.summary: The study found that the use of security-annotated component diagrams significantly improved the correctness of participants' answers without affecting the response time. There was no significant correlation between the time spent on the documentation and the correctness of the answers. Participants perceived the component diagrams as very helpful, while the perception of architectural metrics varied widely.

ethicalConsiderations.privacyMeasures: Confidentiality of participants' data was maintained, with no personal identifying information collected.
